tweets.text:
Im sick of flooding can the @EnvAgency please look at what the Dutch to control rain fall remember you used to be called the National rivers authority üò°
#ollyblogs #LockdownLearning  #OllyRants #flooding #farming https://t.co/109bZBoZ6S

Our teams have been working 24/7 to help communities affected by #StormChristoph. Thanks to all our tireless colleagues on the ground for all their hard work, we‚Äôve protected thousands of homes from flooding. #PrepareActSurvive https://t.co/YXQaxoevsW

@TimGue1 @powell_peter @agricontract @EnvAgency In addition, by the time your idealised river meets the sea it will be well below sea level and will have to be pumped over the sea wall in its entirety.

@johnnyrich @SayNo2SizewellC @Jennife15046404 @KwasiKwarteng @The_ONR @EnvAgency @theCCCuk I don‚Äôt think it is a case of rebuilding EDF - staving off bankruptcy may be more appropriate. If EDF are that good - why do they require the UK Govt to underwrite the cost and programme risk?? Simple answer is they know it will be later and massively over cost.

@group_flood As much as my heart goes out to #Bewdley, at least the @EnvAgency, Councils and Government try to help you in Bewdley. 

Other town ZERO protection or help, not even sandbags. SCC don't even close roads on time, allowing 4x4 to plough through water
@stuartlanegreen @Paul_Bolton_IPC @waitrose Aren‚Äôt masks part of this hazardous waste from wards?

tweets.text: @johnnyrich @SayNo2SizewellC @Jennife15046404 @KwasiKwarteng @The_ONR @EnvAgency @theCCCuk Oh and to quote most of the TV chefs .... EDF already have one in the Oven called Flamanville - nearly a decade late and with mega cost overruns.

@nocotu @SayNo2SizewellC @Jennife15046404 @KwasiKwarteng @The_ONR @EnvAgency @theCCCuk Yes, the CO2 offset will be out of date by then, storage tech will have improved. We can build wind farms at a fraction of the cost, not put toxic waste on an eroding coastline & we can invest in our energy industry instead of paying EdF to rebuild France‚Äôs nuclear power stations

tweets.text: @SayNo2SizewellC @Jennife15046404 @johnnyrich @KwasiKwarteng @The_ONR @EnvAgency @theCCCuk 14 years away. 10 yrs ago - see what PV panels were like / cost the same for batteries compared to here and now. That technology is improving on a quarterly basis and can be deployed virtually instantaneously.... the 2025 version will make the 2021 versions museum pieces.

.@Guardian claims many homes & businesses are at risk of flooding due to ‚Äòruined assets‚Äô, but our blog explains more. 38,000 properties protected during #StormChristoph, no properties flooded due failed permanent defences & all assets winter ready. https://t.co/nB5wHJCW6i

tweets.text: Vehicle check site on the M1 Tibshelf Services. Some interesting results including the trailer pictured which was in a dangerous condition. Blue HGV in the distance, tacho offences leading to ¬£1000 fine from @DVSAEnforcement. #OpDerbyshire #OpTramline https://t.co/lWEKGeKQSO

@realJohnKempf @agricontract @Farmer_Tom_UK @EnvAgency There does appear to be many farmers very vocal about dredging whilst also regularly posting videos/pictures of practices that cause messier soil de-stabilisation

@agricontract @Farmer_Tom_UK @EnvAgency Why are the water channels accumulating silt in the first place? Is it because they have been channeled to run straight and no longer carry sediments without settling, (Victor Schauberger) or that too much sediment is coming from erosion? Or both?

Hard work getting all your ducks in a row on the Dour, let‚Äôs hope this chalk stream gets more love this year ‚ù§Ô∏è may @SE_Rivers_Trust fish pass to be installed @WCCPnews @EnvAgencySE @destdover https://t.co/Ct6SS5fuzP

@SayNo2SizewellC @KwasiKwarteng @The_ONR @EnvAgency @theCCCuk Does that include keeping the equvalent fossils burning until it‚Äôs ready?   Or is that on top of the 5.7m?    And can someone explain what happens the month or so out of every  18 that they are off for refuelling and where our power comes from then? What‚Äôs the plan for that?

@hslyfarms @Rosewood_Farm @billmero @agricontract @sunkfarmer @EnvAgency The more land drains I repair this year the more I realise that fields that look saturated are more often than not just under performing on infiltration. Something I need to work harder on. Wet as hell in the top few inches and fairly dry underneath.

tweets.text: @EdwardCherry10 @agricontract @EnvAgency When did no maintenance become a solution. Farmers could be the solution if allowed and rewarded. Joined up common sense needed. The previous generations didn‚Äôt dig the ditches by hand for fun.

@tractorman07 @agricontract @EnvAgency Take the Ancholme, 27km with 13 inches of fall. EA said its not worth dredging below Brigg as they maintain a certain water level. Would not a deeper channel draw more water from further back when they open the gates into the Humber or am I just being to simplistic?
@agricontract @EnvAgency Obviously simple mate, unfortunately too Obviously simple for experts to grasp.

@Rosewood_Farm @billmero @agricontract @sunkfarmer @EnvAgency The dutch changed their tact in 2001, now a big focus on 1. Retention of excess rainfall in the soil. 2. Storage of excess water in the field or local area. 3. Controlled removal. Intensifying field drainage only further lowers the level exponentially.

tweets.text: @TimGue1 @powell_peter @agricontract @EnvAgency To turn a river into a water chute you would need have a sufficient and even drop along its length.  Otherwise upward pinch points - cities, ports, rocky beds, etc. will generate flooding immediately upstream. Rivers are shaped like trees, not lines, so a massive feat.
@MFRFurness @TM_WRT @agricontract @JamesAgscope @EnvAgency I live and work on those floodplains and I feel that widescale dredging is anything but helpful, it just floods us out faster

@powell_peter @agricontract @EnvAgency The River through our farm is tidal, it has less than half the capacity of 30 years ago, when the tide goes out its efficiency of getting water to the sea is severely hampered, more flooding and less soil capacity. Yes address the whole catchment. At the moment nothing is done.

The @The_WMA state they are not responsible for the River Cong and the @EnvAgencyAnglia whose job is to protect the watercourse have asked the farmer to fill the ditch with mud & move the üêñwhen conditions allowü§¨meanwhile the pollution continues & a Chalkstream will die üêñüí©üíÄ https://t.co/bbkPmAAQy0

@agricontract @EnvAgency Agree sick of flooding but your diagrams are misleading. On clay and silty clay loams for example the top soil layer seals and sheds water quickly without percolating to lower levels. Silt may sit in low lying rivers but not upland ones etc need rivers to reconnect flood plains

@Rosewood_Farm @MFRFurness @TM_WRT @agricontract @JamesAgscope @EnvAgency @JanetHughes TBF 20 years ago these channels were well maintained by the NRA as it was then, little and often (ev 4-5yrs in our case) worked for drainage and minimised harm to the environment. Now a lot of waterways are fantastic habitats but inefficient waterways 1/2

tweets.text: @AWP_BackCountry @Feargal_Sharkey @EnvAgency @GeorgeMonbiot @CraigBennett3 Why did you delete the Dearie Me s.?They were super cute.

@farmers_against @Feargal_Sharkey @EnvAgency @GeorgeMonbiot @CraigBennett3 So we got there in the end. You dont have any qualifications on the matter which makes you the 'armchair expert'. You might want to rethink using this term in future if you cant back it up. Good night 'Farmers Against Misinformation'

@tractorman07 @agricontract @EnvAgency Seem to remember us having this conversation more than once Malc, It shows how much notice they take, when we have to get the bestest crayons out to get the message across. One day they might listen, one day being when majority of the country is under water. Excellent video Olly.
@philipraynor @EnvAgency It is, that's what we'll be doing.

@MFRFurness @agricontract @EnvAgency What a load of üí© @EnvAgency, ‚Äòvision, adaptation and resilience‚Äô!!ü§£ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Dredge the rivers, do what you should be doing.  Take a leaf out of the IDB‚Äôs in The Fens, they know what they‚Äôre doing.  Obviously none of the EA executives live alongside a flooding river.

@MarethBassett @slowtheflow_UK @EnvAgency @WildTroutTrust @BBCWinterwatch Exactly. When Stevenage recreated as a new town post war, built 5 large ‚Äò#watermeadows‚Äô to hold back #urban #runoff to protect #riverbeane d/stream. Works, but release quite quickly. Scope for natural flood management within them to further improve. @EnvAgencyAnglia @HMWTBadger
We've been hard at work setting up pumps to remove flood water at Didsbury this morning. https://t.co/r0lxUkhbeH

@bentd76 @agricontract @EnvAgency And meanwhile get the EA to sort this mess out in Ollies field buy sorting the levelsout and getting the pump on the far right to work. Then we can fix the other farms. https://t.co/ZN40QygI7W
@AWP_BackCountry @Feargal_Sharkey @EnvAgency @GeorgeMonbiot @CraigBennett3 I don‚Äôt need the attention that you obviously crave. Good night Austen.

tweets.text: @audlemagronpaul @agricontract @EnvAgency The systems broken, one mans soil can be as good as you like, but if everyone else‚Äôs is pouring down hillsides and off farms, his effort is wasted. Rivers won‚Äôt be dredged so may as well focus on everyone slowing the flow.
@ChrisTroutFly @TM_WRT @agricontract @JamesAgscope @EnvAgency May be move then - the picture you paint sounds awful . Yorkshire may be ? https://t.co/HJl63n8aXP

@bentd76 Breaking it some more or just keeping it functioning ? I walk @agricontract s ground - with over 1100mm of rain in 2019/20 it‚Äôs wet. He takes care of his bit - the drains and no-til, but the @EnvAgency need to do theirs. Repeated calls for action have been ignored.

@MFRFurness @TM_WRT @agricontract @JamesAgscope @EnvAgency I live  & work in Somerset. Bare maize stubbles, thin compacted leys, box hedges flailed to fuck all, 4 silage cuts a year, heavy machinery daily, solar farms, new housing, crated veal feedlots ‚Äúfarm workers‚Äù new cottages/converted barns, easy to scrape concrete yards 1/2

@agricontract @EnvAgency Most rivers are tidal at the bottom. High tide plus an entire catchments worth of water moved to the bottom could be disastrous.  All the rainfall rather than be spread across an entire catchment is then moved to one place.
